docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S the only formal party some people are ever invited to. It's the only couture dress many women will ever own. It's the only catered event many people ever attend. There's no mystery to why people love weddings and are thrilled to sit through them again and again. And in today's popular culture, geared to pander and give the people what they want and only what they want, audiences are getting plenty of opportunity to sit through weddings. Again and again. From all the wedding movies, weddings in sitcoms, issues of magazines devoted to weddings and from the sheer size of the traditional ''grand finale'' wedding dresses on the runways right now, it might be reasonable to guess that there are more weddings than ever. There aren't. Bride's Magazine's statistics show that the number of weddings per year in the United States has hovered steadily around 2.4 million since the 70's.

headline.main: The Wedding Dress That Ate Hollywood

docs.abstract: Weddings are popular theme in movies, television shows and magazine, as well as finales of designer fashion shows; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''THERE are no second acts in American lives,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in his notes for ''The Last Tycoon,'' a fictionalized portrait of a tragic movie mogul. Had Fitzgerald met the individuals profiled here, he might have reconsidered that statement. After years in one career and life style, these Long Islanders have reinvented themselves and created ''second acts'' in their lives. MARK FEINBERG For Mark Feinberg, a career in sales and marketing for almost 15 years involved a daily commute of up to four hours a day, as well as regular travel throughout the United States and to Hong Kong and China.

headline.main: After One Career, It's Time To Start a Second or Third

docs.abstract: Profiles of some Long Islanders who have started second and third careers: licensed massage therapist Mark Feinberg, barbecue restaurant owner Stanley Singer, psychologist June Spirer, home builder Jane Giovanna Julianelli, pregnancy wardrobe designer Cherie Serota and cooking school owner Barbara Sheridan; photos (Special Life Styles Issue) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE employed only in futuristic weapons, cardiovascular surgery, CD players and other high-tech gadgets, the laser has become the beauty industry's favorite new power tool. Lasers are showing up in salon ads and dermatologist brochures, promising to zap away unwanted body hair, wrinkles and leg veins. But laser technology is developing so rapidly, it's difficult for consumers to discern what is safe and effective. ''A laser is something you use to deliver a certain amount of energy in order to destroy a precise target,'' Dr. David Biro, a dermatologist in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, said. ''Like a smart bomb, it selectively attacks a site without damaging any of the surrounding tissue.''
docs.abstract: Advances in laser technology are drawing doctors and others to lucrative field of cosmetic dermatology; technolgy is developing so rapidly that it is hard for consumers to discern whether procedures to zap away unwanted body hair, wrinkles and leg veins are safe and effective; photo (M)
